speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me about your pregnancy? Was it normal?

speaker: Patient
text: "I don't really know, I was born, and my mom said she didn't get any special care before I was born."

speaker: Doctor
text: What's your current condition? Are you breathing on your own or do you need any assistance?

speaker: Patient
text: "I'm breathing okay, but it's hard sometimes. And... I don't like the way I look."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about what you mean by "I don't like the way I look"? Is there something specific that's bothering you about your appearance?

speaker: Patient
text: "My skin looks funny, and I don't like the spots on my skin. They don't go away when I press on them."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you show me exactly where these spots are on your skin?

speaker: Patient
text: "Okay... they're all over my arms and legs. And my eyes are weird too. They're all cloudy."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about what you mean by "cloudy" eyes? Are they painful or do you have any trouble seeing?

speaker: Patient
text: "I don't really see things very well. It's like looking through a misty window. And sometimes I hear nothing, like there's no sound at all."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about when you started noticing these vision problems? Was it right after birth or did it develop over time?

speaker: Patient
text: "I don't know, I just know that I couldn't see very well from the beginning. I've never seen anything clearly, not even my mom's face."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if you have any other symptoms besides the skin spots, cloudy eyes, and vision problems? Are you having any trouble eating or digesting food?

speaker: Patient
text: "I don't know, I just eat and drink what my mom gives me, and it makes me feel okay, I guess. But sometimes I get a funny feeling in my chest, like it's beating too fast or something."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you describe this funny feeling in your chest? Is it a constant sensation or does it come and go?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's always there, even when I'm not doing anything. It's like a humming noise, but it's coming from inside my chest. Sometimes it gets louder and feels like it's going to burst."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if you've noticed any changes in your skin spots or the way they feel? Are they itchy or tender to the touch?

speaker: Patient
text: "They're always there, and they don't feel good. It's like they're burning, but not hot. They don't itch, but sometimes they feel tight, like they're squeezing my skin."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the sensation of the skin spots feeling tight and squeezing your skin? Is it a constant sensation or does it come and go?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's always there, but sometimes it feels worse. Like, when I move my arms or legs, it gets a little better, but then it comes back. It's hard to explain, but it feels like they're trying to get out or something."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about this sensation of the skin spots feeling like they're trying to get out? Is it a painful sensation or more of a discomfort?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's not really painful, but it's uncomfortable. It's like they're... pulsing or something. Like my heart is beating in my skin, but it's not my heart."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the sensation of the skin spots pulsing or feeling like your heart is beating in your skin? Is this sensation localized to specific areas or is it widespread?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's all over my body, but it's worse on my arms and legs. Sometimes it feels like my whole body is pulsing, like my heart is beating everywhere."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if you've had any fevers or chills since birth?

speaker: Patient
text: "I don't think so... I don't really feel hot or cold, just... different. Like, my body feels like it's always trying to do something, but I don't know what."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about what you mean by "my body feels like it's always trying to do something"? What do you think it might be trying to do?

speaker: Patient
text: "I don't know... it's like my body is trying to beat faster or something. It feels like my heart is trying to get out or something. I don't know what it's trying to do, but it feels like it's always trying to do something."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the sensation of your heart beating in your skin? Is it a rhythmic beating or is it more irregular?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's not really rhythmic, it's more like... a hum. It's always there, and it's not very strong, but it's always there. Sometimes it feels like it's getting stronger, like it's going to get louder, but it never does."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if you've noticed any changes in your skin spots or the way they feel when you're exposed to different temperatures or environments?

speaker: Patient
text: "I don't think so... I just feel like they're always there. But sometimes when I'm near the window and the sun is shining, I feel like they get a little worse. It's hard to explain, but it's like they're more noticeable or something."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about what you mean by "they get a little worse" when you're near the window and the sun is shining? Is it a physical sensation or more of a visual change?

speaker: Patient
text: "I don't know, it's just that they seem more... noticeable, I guess. Like, I can see them more clearly when the sun is shining. And sometimes it feels like they're... glowing or something. It's weird, I don't know how to explain it."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you show me exactly what you mean by "glowing" when you're near the window and the sun is shining? Is it a specific area of your skin or is it more widespread?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's all over my body, but it's more noticeable on my arms and legs. When I'm near the window and the sun is shining, it's like... my skin is shining too. It's hard to explain, but it's like it's reflecting the light or something."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if you've noticed any changes in your skin spots or the way they feel when you're exposed to different types of light?

speaker: Patient
text: "Yes, I think they get worse when I'm near the window and the sun is shining. But sometimes when I'm in a dark room, they feel a little better. It's like the light makes them more... noticeable, I guess."

speaker: Doctor
text: I've asked all my questions, and now it's time to make a diagnosis. Based on your symptoms, I'm going to request some test results to confirm my suspicions. REQUEST TEST: Skin Biopsy Please note that I'll need to examine your skin more closely to get a better understanding of the skin spots. A skin biopsy will help us determine the cause of the skin lesions and whether they're related to any underlying condition. Once I receive the test results, I'll be able to provide a more definitive diagnosis and recommend the appropriate treatment plan.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: NOT AVAILABLE.
